Ballet dancer Carlos Acosta is known for powerful leaps that make him seem to fly.
Those leaps have earned him comparisons with Nureyev and Baryshnikov.
Growing up in Cuba in the 1980s, Carlos Acosta would've much preferred a different comparison to soccer star Pele.
The young Acosta would go on to win a top international ballet prize at 16, dance as the first black Romeo at London's Royal Ballet, and choreograph a ballet based on his childhood in Cuba.
He's traveled a long way since then and it's a journey he chronicles in his memoir ""No Way Home.
Home was one of the poorest neighborhoods outside Havana.
His was a mixed family - his mother was white and his father black - when there was still a lot of prejudice.
But Carlos Acosta remembers feeling embraced by this small world known as Los Pinos.
People live in a sense of community.
Everybody help each other.
And sometimes we had rice and beans, and the neighbor would lend you some eggs; somebody else would lend you another vegetables.
And then you would do the same thing for another neighbor in need.
And of course there was this great place, which is called La Finka(ph), which is sort of like a forest nearby.
You call it in the book an enchanted forest.
That's right, because, you know, it was natural caves that the trees will form, birds, a lot of tropical fruits, and there was a lot of legends around that place.
You know, people would think that the owls were just spirits, you know...
Spirits.
Yeah, it was magical.
It was sort of like an innocence that later on disappeared.
You describe yourself as running in the streets with other boys when you were young - a ruffian within your world.
Yeah, because, I mean, I didn't like school.
I mean, if I would have carried on like that, God knows what my future would have been.
In fact, some of my friends result into stealings and many of them went to prison.
Well, your father didn't let that happen.
He was a truck driver, working class, but had wanted something for you.
Because partly, I think, I was the youngest member of my family.
And I was the only chance that he had to make it right, and so he wasn't going to let that chance to slip away from his fingers.
So he was determined from all cost to make something good out of me.
You tell about how your father came up with this vision of ballet.
It wasn't anything he had direct experience with, it was something that he discovered in a silent movie theatre as a young boy.
That's right, and then he got kicked out.
It was a movie theatre for white people only.

This is a little part of the description you have: he didn't know what the peculiar dance was, but the ballerinas immediately spoke to his senses as they spun around like Japanese parasols: elegant, delicate and light.
That's right.
Of course you didn't really see yourself as up there on the stage with the dancing parasols.
I wanted to be a football player.
That's always been my ambition, but he didn't want to hear it.
So off you were sent to ballet school, like it or not.
Unfortunately you had talent - unfortunately for you, I mean.
At that time you couldn't get kicked out.
But you tried, didn't you?

Tell us about that moment, that really you embraced what it seemed everyone else knew, and that was that ballet was going to be your art.

Which means, in a sense, at least momentarily, fly.
Fly, yeah.
It's, like, what they call the hanging time.
You know, we have all these leaps but it's just to have illusion that you'll never come down.
Cuba always does seem to draw you back.

Well, let's start with Los Angeles.
What exactly is Rocky Delgadillo doing?
He quietly, for several months, has been investigating insurance industry practices which involves canceling coverage for individual policyholders after they submit claims for medical care.
So after they get sick.
And he believes that this might violate some insurance and health care laws in California.
And what do the health care companies say about that?
The companies believe they're operating within the law.
They believe that it's necessary and unfortunate that in a rare number of cases they are forced to drop people who they believe lied on their applications for coverage about preexisting conditions.

Many of these patients have subsequently sued the insurers, alleging that they were honest and may have made inadvertent errors or forgotten something that their doctor put on their chart 20 years ago that's inconsequential now and are being wrongly cancelled because the insurers are trying to avoid their costs.
And I understand he has set up a Web site where people can log their complaints and tell their stories about what's happened to them?
Yes.
As far as I can tell, it's the first of its kind in this kind of an investigation.
And they are looking for information from patients.
Also they're looking for information from hospitals and physicians and current and former employees of health insurance companies about these practices and others.
It's a pretty wide-ranging investigation, but initially at least they're focusing on this cancellation practice known also as rescission in the industry.
And Lisa, in New York State Attorney General Andrew Cuomo is also investigating health care companies but for something different.
He's actually looking into fraud and whether or not patients are being overcharged.
Exactly.

He's looking at when patients go out of their insurance networks to physicians and they believe that their insurance company is going to pay 80 percent of those costs and they go in for a physician visit and they learn that their bill at the end, that their insurance carrier might pay $62 for that and their part of the bill is $138.
And they're trying to figure out: what just happened to me?
So what do the insurance companies say they're doing there?

Well, the insurance companies say they're providing a valuable service, that they are trying to hold down costs for consumers and patients and for the employers that also chip in for these health care premiums.
And they're trying to discourage patients from going out of network, right?
Absolutely, yeah.
Because their in-network doctors, for the privilege of being in their networks and seeing most of their patients, they agree to accept lower rates.
Lisa, are there similar issues happening elsewhere?
Or is this simply in New York and California for the moment?
Well, for now this is the first I'm aware that law enforcement authorities lately have gotten involved in looking at health insurers.
I think there's been some activity in Florida, but mostly this is stuff that's supervised by regulators.

Because most big insurance companies - it's a highly consolidated industry - operate nationwide and in many states, the practices look similar across the country and the complaints that I hear from people across the country are very similar.
But this is the first pass that law enforcement officials are taking at it that I'm aware of.
